newsitem.title: CYPRUS: Cyprus protests at Turkish remarks on missiles.
newsitem.headline: Cyprus protests at Turkish remarks on missiles.

text.p: Cyprus protested to the UN on Tuesday over Turkish remarks that it would not tolerate the deployment of long-range missiles on the divided island.

"For as long as there is a strong military presence of Turkey in Cyprus we have an obligation to build our own defence and in doing this we are not going to seek approval from Turkey," Foreign Minister Alecos Michaelides told Reuters.

President Glafcos Clerides protested to UN Cyprus special representative Han Sung-Joo over Turkish remarks on Monday concerning Cyprus's reported intention of purchasing a Russian missile system for the island.
"No one should expect that Turkey may tolerate the deployment of long-range missiles, threatening its security," Foreign Ministry spokesman Omar Akbel said, according to Anatolia news agency.
Greek Cypriot officials have kept silent on the reports the government is interested in purchasing Russian-built S300 surface-to-air missiles to boost its air defences.
"We are going to buy anything we think is necessary for our defence. That is our moral obligation," said Michaelides.

The heavily militarised eastern Mediterranean island has been divided since Turkey invaded the northern third in 1974 after a brief Greek Cypriot coup in Nicosia engineered by the military ruling in Greece at the time.

Turkey has some 30,000 troops deployed in northern Cyprus, declared a breakaway Turkish Cypriot state only Ankara recognises and one of the most heavily militarised areas in the world, according to UN reports.

The 10,000 strong Greek Cypriot national guard is engaged in a comprehensive programme to upgrade its capabilities but remains significantly weaker than the Turkish forces in the north. It also has a defence pact with close ally Greece.

The Greek Cypriot side says a significant step towards defusing tension on the island and paving the way to a comprehensive settlement would be to demilitarise the island. The Turkish Cypriot side says demilitarisation can be discussed only as part of a more comprehensive package on the Cyprus problem.
Michaelides, who described Akbel's comments as "unacceptable" said the government is ready to embark on a discussion for the demilitarisation of the island "tomorrow"
"We don't need arms in Cyprus but it must be demilitarised totally," he said.
